references.B85STE01NAUS: Stebbins, R. C. 1985. A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xiv + 336 pp.
references.B70FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.
references.A91SMI03NAUS: Smith, H. M., D. Chizar, and W. Marmie. 1991. Peripheral variation in the lizard SCELOPORUS OLIVACEUS, and its hybridization with S. UNDULATUS. Bull. Maryland Herp. Soc. 27(3):128-145.
references.A83COL04NAUS: Cole, C. J. 1983. Specific status of the North American fence lizards, SCELOPORUS UNDULATUS and SCELOPORUS OCCIDENTALIS, with comments on chromosome variation. Am. Mus. Novitates (2768):1-13.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.B85ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1985. Handbook of reptiles and amphibians of Florida. Part two. Lizards, turtles & crocodilians. Windward Pub., Inc., Miami. 191 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.A89SMI05NAUS: Smith, H. M., and D. Chizar. 1989. The subspecific identity of the population of SCELOPORUS UNDULATUS sympatric with S. OCCIDENTALIS. Bull. Maryland Herp. Soc. 25(4):143-150.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.B82HAM01NAUS: Hammerson, G. A. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Colorado. Colorado Division of Wildlife, Denver. vii + 131 pp.
references.B95PAL01NAUS: Palmer, W. M., and A. L. Braswell. 1995. Reptiles of North Carolina. North Carolina State Museum of Natural Sciences, University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
references.A86TIN01NAUS: Tinkle, D. W., and A. E. Dunham. 1986. Comparative life histories of two syntopic sceloporine lizards. Copeia 1986:1-18.
references.B92SIT01NAUS: Sites, J. W., Jr., et al. 1992. A review of phylogenetic hypotheses for lizards of the genus SCELOPORUS (Phrynosomatidae):implications for ecological and evolutionary studies. Bull. Am. Mus. Nat. Hist. (213):1-110.
references.B94MIT01NCGP: Mitchell, J. C. 1994. The reptiles of Virginia. Washington, DC: Smithsonian Institution Press.
references.A94PAR01NAUS: Parker, W. S. 1994. Demography of the fence lizard, SCELOPORUS UNDULATUS, in northern Mississippi. Copeia 1994:136-152.
references.B99BAR01SEGP: Bartlett, R.D. and P.P. Bartlett. 1999. Field guide to Florida reptiles and amphibians. Gulf Publishing Co, Houston, TX. 280 p.

habitat_description:
The range extends from New York to Florida. It encompasses areas of South Dakota, and central Indiana. In Mexico, populations occur along the Gulf Coast south into Zacatecas (Natureserve.org; Stebbins 2003). The elevational range has been estimated from near sea level up to 3050 meters (Stebbins 2003). The populations observed on Long Island, New York are most likely the result of introductions (Feinberg 2004 (as referenced by Natureserve.org). This species inhabits riparian areas, but also habitats with bare rock, talus, and scree. Populations are established in deserts, and arid areas where individuals can be observed in cliffs, sand dunes, shrubland, chaparral, suburban settings, orchards, conifer woodland, hardwood woodland, and mixed woodland (Natureserve.org).

This species is known to burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter, but also in standing snag and hollow trees.  Eggs are laid in soft soil, and underground. The eastern fence lizard is regarded as species that is primarily arboreal. However, several populations are also described as terrestrial, or saxicolus. When active, these lizards are often seen basking in open, sunny situations. During periods of inactivity or hiding, this species retreats to crevices (Natureserve.org).

Recent work has split this species into 4 species S. undulatus, S. tristichus, S. cowlesi, and S. consobrinus.
